newsitem.title: USA: "Long Island Lolita" is denied prison move.
newsitem.headline: "Long Island Lolita" is denied prison move.

text.p: A judge Wednesday rejected a request by "Long Island Lolita" Amy Fisher to be transferred from a prison where she alleges she was raped by guards.
Fisher is serving a 5- to 15-year sentence for the May 19, 1992, shooting of the wife of her lover Joey Buttafuoco. Mary Jo Buttafuoco still has a bullet lodged in her face.

The case grabbed national headlines and was the subject of several made-for-TV movies about the love affair between Joey Buttafuoco and then 16-year-old Fisher, who was dubbed the "Long Island Lolita".
He served four months of a 1-1/3- to 4-year sentence for the statutory rape of Fisher.
State officials said her lawsuit claiming unspecified damages against the New York State Department of Correctional Services and several guards for her alleged rape in jail would continue.
In a 109-page ruling, U.S. District Court Judge Richard Arcara in Buffalo, N.Y. refused to grant a preliminary injunction to have Fisher, 22, transferred to another prison.
But the Judge indicated that there is a problem with inmates and staff at Albion having sex, which is against the law but was not illegal at the time Fisher said the alleged rapes occurred.
Fisher, who wanted to be moved to a prison in Connecticut to be closer to home, was turned down for parole last month from Albion state prison in western New York.

Judge Arcara questioned the reliability of Fisher's story as well as testimony from her mother and a psychologist hired by Fisher, who alleges she was raped several times by a prison guard shortly after going to Albion.
